title: Markets Try To Steady Themselves After Wednesday’s WTO Nightmare
text:
Halloween came early on Wednesday, the WTO treating the global markets to a nasty trick as they gave the US the green light to impose tariffs on $7.5 billion in European goods.

After yesterday’s dizzying losses, the markets attempted to steady on Thursday, with mixed success. The , which was one of the worst hit as French wine made America’s naughty list, managed to eke out a 0.2% rise after the bell, with the IBEX and also in the green.

The , however, wasn’t so lucky. Certainly not helped by BP (LON: ) and Shell (LON: ) falling around 1% apiece, the UK index lost another 25 points, forcing it back to 7100 and leaving it at a 5-week low. This despite the pound continuing to hold at its own one-month nadir against the dollar; the currency has spent the week treading water against the greenback, almost completely ignoring Boris Johnson’s ham-fisted attempts at a .

After the panic caused by the manufacturing PMIs earlier in the week, it’ll be interesting to see whether or not Thursday’s services figures have the same effect. The Eurozone-wide reading is expected to sit at , while the UK number is set to slip from ; a bit later on, the US is then forecast to drop from 56.4 to 55.1 month-on-month.
